docs.title: Home
docs.text:
Welcome to the Max Planck Tandem Group in Holobiont Research!

We are a research group at Universidad Nacional de Colombia focused on advancing knowledge in the mechanisms that determine the diversity patterns of microbial communities of agricultural and livestock systems. Our work combines molecular biology and bioinformatics to address fundamental challenges in microbial ecology.

docs.title: Research Highlights
docs.text:
Recent Achievement

We recently published our work on the factors that determine the microbial diversity in the rizhosphere of the Theobroma cacao wild relatives in ISME communications. Read more →

  • Community genetic diversity as a public good for evolution of innovative functions
  • The genomic basis for cooperation in bacteria
  • Tools for exploring fine-level diversity in microbial communities

docs.title: Research Overview
docs.text: Our group investigates the mechanisms that determine the diversity patterns of microbial communities of agricultural and livestock systems. Our work combines molecular biology and bioinformatics to address fundamental challenges in microbial ecology.

docs.title: Area 1: Community genetic diversity as a public good for evolution of innovative functions
docs.text:
Comparative genomics suggests that a large fraction of the metabolic genes present in most bacterial genomes have been horizontally exchanged. The higher number of HGT cases among physiological and overlapping niche-dependent bacteria suggests that ecological interactions are a key factor favoring gene exchange in bacteria. However, most HGT studies have been conducted by analyzing organisms that did not coexist in the exact same habitat, confounding the identification of the putative donor, the time scale of the event, and the functional relevance of the exchange. I believed that a better understanding of the role of ecology in HGT requires a more detailed examination of microbial interactions on a temporal and spatial scale. My previous work suggests that cooperative adaptations (e.g., syntrophism) may be facilitated by HGT, however, how genomes change and adjust to these conditions is unknown. To address how novel functions evolve, I will study the cooperative degradation of newly synthesized chemical compounds (e.g. chlorinated compounds, artificial sweeteners) in different systems (e.g. bioreactor, human microbiomes). Using non-disruptive sampling technologies (e.g. sucrose gradients), stable isotope probing, physicochemical quantification, metagenomics and transcriptomics, my goal is to elucidate the effect of genomic changes in genome diversity that facilitate cooperative interactions. This work will have a direct impact on our understanding of how microbial communities assemble and how interaction within an environment leads to the evolution of functions (metabolic pathways and services).

Key Publications:

  • Author et al. (2024). "Paper Title". Journal Name. [PDF] [Code]

docs.title: Area 2: The genomic basis for cooperation in bacteria
docs.text:
Degradation of most compounds requires the cooperation of phylogenetically unrelated bacteria. While these processes are relevant to understanding how microbial communities assemble and evolve, how recognition and complementation mechanisms arise is unknown. My previous work suggests that cooperative adaptations (e.g., syntrophism) may be facilitated by HGT, however, how genomes change and adjust to these conditions is unknown. To address how these mechanisms evolve, I will study the cooperative degradation of newly synthesized chemical compounds (e.g. chlorinated compounds, artificial sweeteners) in different systems (e.g. bioreactor, human microbiomes). Using non-disruptive sampling technologies, stable isotope probing, physicochemical quantification, metagenomics and transcriptomics, my goal is to elucidate genomic changes that facilitate cooperative interactions. This work will have a direct impact on our understanding of how microbial communities assemble and how interaction within an environment leads to the evolution of functions (metabolic pathways and services).

Key Publications:

  • Author et al. (2023). "Paper Title". Conference Name. [PDF] [Code]

docs.title: Area 3: Tools for exploring fine-level diversity in microbial communities
docs.text: Sequencing of universal genetic markers, such as the 16S rRNA gene, is the de facto molecular tool for the identification of bacterial composition in studies of microbial communities. However, due to their high conservation, these markers are not suitable for accurately differentiating between more recently diverged lineages and, therefore, the contribution of this diversity remains unknown. Assessment of such fine-level diversity has become ecologically and evolutionarily important, as lineages within the same species may have differences in evolutionary history, gene content, function, and ecology. Exploration of this fine-level diversity has been scarce due to the laborious search and extraction of gene orthologs present in specific taxonomic groups and the difficulty of finding low-redundancy primers that can efficiently amplify the homologous region. To overcome these limitations, we present a python-based application, called PROTÉGÉ (PROTEIN coding genes for high-resolution phylogenetic labeling), which integrates automatic search and extraction of orthologous genes with in-silico design, selection and evaluation of low-degeneracy primers. for high-throughput sequencing.

docs.title: Relationship of cocoa (Theobroma cacao L.) seed microbial endophyte diversity with germination and grafting of regional materials from Tumaco, Nariño.
docs.text:
Ongoing Project

Duration: 2022 - Present Funding: UNAL-AGROSAVIA

This research proposal seeks, first, to explore the differences and similarities of the endophytic communities (fungi and bacteria) of regional materials and universal cocoa rootstocks, in order to determine if there is a relationship between these endophytic communities and grafting success. Second, it seeks to isolate endophytic microorganisms with growth-promoting capacity and evaluate their effect on the grafting success of regional cocoa materials. This knowledge will allow the development of technologies to improve the propagation schemes of materials from the department of Nariño.

Objectives:

  • Objective 1
  • Objective 2
  • Objective 3

Team Members: [Names]

docs.title: Diversity of the microbiome associated with wild plants of Theobroma cacao L. and sister species in the Amazon and Choco regions.
docs.text:
Ongoing Project

Duration: 2022 - Present Funding: COLCIENCIAS

In the case of Theobroma cacao, very little is known about the composition of the microbial communities associated with the plant under cultivated conditions and there are no reports on the composition under wild conditions. The lack of information on the presence of microorganisms under wild conditions is due to the fact that the parental plants that gave rise to the cultivated cocoa materials were extracted from their natural conditions and subsequently located in other areas of development and production. Therefore, determining the diversity of the cocoa microbiome under an evolutionary framework and under wild conditions offers a unique opportunity to explore, among other topics, the effect of ecosystem diversity on the composition of the cocoa microbiota, the effect of the evolutionary proximity of sister species and genera on the composition of the communities that colonize their tissues, and to determine patterns of coexistence within the microbial communities that can be associated with diseased and healthy tissues in wild and cultivated states.

Objectives:

  • Objective 1
  • Objective 2
  • Objective 3

Team Members: [Names]

docs.title: Development and evaluation of culture methodologies for the recovery of rumen microorganisms using metabarcoding.
docs.text:
Ongoing Project

Duration: 2022 - Present Funding: Max Planck Society

This project seeks to develop a cultivation strategy to improve the recovery of ruminal microorganisms. The strategy combines the evaluation of cultivation parameters with population analysis using metabarcoding. Among the objectives of this project was the evaluation of alternative culture methods for the isolation of rumen microorganisms, this objective was approached from the development of eight culture media, which have been described in the literature as suitable for the recovery of anaerobic microorganisms, in addition to the use of two variables; A dilution variable that has been described as a tool to favor poorly cultured populations and an incubation time variable, trying to represent and benefit the metabolism of microorganisms of slow growth or dependent on metabolites produced by others.

Objectives:

  • Objective 1
  • Objective 2
  • Objective 3

Team Members: [Names]

docs.title: Datasets
docs.text: We are committed to open science and make our research data publicly available whenever possible.

docs.title: Theobroma cacao L. Seed-Borne Microbial Endophytes
docs.text:
Dataset Information

Publication: Toloza-Moreno et al., 2024, Microbial Ecology Data Type: 16S rRNA and ITS amplicon sequencing Samples: 266 samples from different T. cacao genotypes (regional, recently liberates and comercial) and different tissues (roots, leaves, cotyledons and stems).

Contents:

  • Raw sequencing reads (FASTQ)
  • Processed OTU/ASV tables
  • Sample metadata
  • Analysis scripts

NCBI BioProject: PRJNA1011283 | Supplementary Data | Analysis Code

docs.title: Public Data
docs.text: All published datasets are freely available through the links above. No registration required.

docs.title: Data Standards
docs.text:
We follow community standards for data sharing:

  • Sequencing data: FAIR principles, MIxS metadata standards
  • Genomes: NCBI submission guidelines
  • Code: Version control with Git, documentation with README files

docs.title: Citation
docs.text: If you use our datasets, please cite the original publication and include the data repository accession numbers.

docs.title: Software & Tools
docs.text: We develop and maintain open-source software tools for microbial ecology and genomics research.

docs.title: PopMAG
docs.text:
A Nextflow pipeline for population genetics analysis based on Metagenome-Assembled Genomes (MAGs). The pipeline processes MAGs alongside paired-end sequencing short reads to perform quality assessment, abundance profiling, variant calling, and population genomics analyses, ending in an interactive visualization dashboard built with R shiny.

Includes:

  • MAG Quality control and preprocessing.
  • Microbial community profiling.
  • Abundance calculation and variant calling.
  • Population genomics and functional analysis.
  • Visualization and reporting.

GitHub Repository

docs.title: Scripts & Utilities
docs.text:
We share useful scripts and utilities on our GitHub organization:

  • Data processing scripts - Common data manipulation tasks
  • Visualization templates - Publication-ready figure templates
  • Analysis notebooks - Jupyter/R notebooks for reproducible analysis

HolobiontResearch GitHub

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
We welcome contributions to our software projects! Please see the contributing guidelines in each repository for more information.

If you find bugs or have feature requests, please open an issue on the relevant GitHub repository.

docs.title: Microbial Ecology
docs.text:
Course Information

Code: 2018797 Semester: First semester of the year Credits: 4

An introduction to the principles of microbial ecology, covering history, experimental and sampling methods, and the principles of use and bioinformatics analyses of high-throughput sequencing-generated data.

Topics:

  • Microbial diversity
  • Microbial interactions
  • Methods in microbial ecology
  • Bioinformatics analyses of sequencing data

Prerequisites: Basic ecology,

docs.title: Biology of Microorganisms
docs.text:
Semester: Both semesters Credits: 4

Fundamentals of microbiology for biology majors.

docs.title: Recommended Reading
docs.text:
Textbooks:

  • David L. Kirchman, Processes in Microbial Ecology, Oxford University Press, ISBN: 978-0-19-958692-9
  • Tom Fenchel and Bland J. Finlay, Ecology and Evolution in Anoxic Worlds, Oxford University Press, ISBN: 978-0-19-854837-9

Online Resources:

  • QIIME2 Tutorials
  • Happy Belly Bioinformatics

  • Anvi'o

docs.title: Thesis Guidelines
docs.text:
For students working on their thesis in our group:

  1. Proposal: Submit a 1-2 pages research proposal
  2. Progress Reports: Weekly meetings with advisor
  3. Writing: Follow Universidad Nacional de Colombia thesis format guidelines
  4. Defense: Schedule group meetings at least 4 weeks in advance

Download Thesis Template

docs.title: Mentoring
docs.text:
We are committed to mentoring the next generation of scientists. Our mentoring philosophy includes:

  • Regular one-on-one meetings
  • Professional development opportunities
  • Conference attendance support
  • Career guidance

Interested in joining our group? See Join Us.

docs.title: Prof. Alejando Caro-Quintero
docs.text:
Position: Assistant Professor of Biology Department Email: acaroq@unal.edu.co Office: Building, Room 123

Bio: I am an assistant professor in the Department of Biology at the National University of Colombia (Bogotá). I have a degree in microbiology from the Universidad de los Andes, a master's degree from the University of Puerto Rico Recinto Universitario de Mayaguez (UPRM) and a PhD from the Georgia Institute of Techonology (GeorgiaTech).

My research focuses on understanding the mechanisms that determine the diversity patterns of microbial communities associated with systems of agricultural and livestock importance, as well as elucidating through genomics and metagenomics the evolutionary adaptations that lead to the strengthening of these associations (e.g., plant endophytes).

docs.title: Prospective PhD Students
docs.text:
If you're interested in pursuing a PhD with our group:

  1. Review our research - Familiarize yourself with our recent publications
  2. Check requirements - Ensure you meet university admission criteria
  3. Reach out - Email Prof. Alejandro Caro-Quintero with:
    • Your CV
    • Transcript
    • Brief description of your research interests
    • Why you want to join our group
